list.title: Question 1
list.content:
A dataset has a minimum value of $12$, a lower quartile of $18$ and a median of $22$.
A partially drawn boxplot of the dataset is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ddf128f-8f66-46d8-a38c-dd434bc5606f/images/8550d330-aae0-4c97-a1bc-7137cfa9cc4e/AA1147_q.JPEG)


It is known that the lower boundary for outliers is $9$.

- Find the interquartile range. [2]

The maximum value is known to be $26$.

- Hence, complete the sketch of
the boxplot on the grid above. [3]

- Describe the distribution of the dataset.[1]

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Consider the function $\displaystyle f(x)=b+\frac{4}{x+a}$, $\hspace{1em}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$.
The equation of the vertical asymptote of $f(x)$ is $x=2$ and $f(\tfrac{2}{3})=0$.

- Write down the value of $a$.[1]

- Hence, find the value of $b$. [3]

- Hence, write down the equation of the horizontal asymptote.[1]

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined as $f(x)=3e^{\frac{x}{2}}$ where $x \in \mathrm{R}$ and is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e175b6d9-563c-4c8f-a8fa-b8e3ca7ce99f/images/b05207b3-e706-477a-85d6-ff97ee420070/AA1180_q.JPEG)



- Write down the equation of the asymptote of $f(x)$. [1]

- Write down the $y-$intercept of $f(x)$. [1]

- Hence, or otherwise, sketch the inverse of $f(x)$ on the image above. Make sure any asymptotes and/or intercepts are clearly marked. [2]

- Determine the domain of the inverse of $f(x)$. [1]

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
In the expansion of $(a+bx)^6$, the coefficient of the $x^3$ term is $-2$ times the coefficient of the $x^4$ term.
Determine the value of $\displaystyle \frac{a}{b}$.

list.title: Question 5
Question 6
list.content:
An isosceles trapezium is inscribed inside a semi-circle of radius $r\,$centimetres, where $r>0$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/679151b0-9bb0-41ea-bd04-7ee3212a82ef/images/f8008491-9a54-492f-96ac-04fa9b90bf37/AA1158_q.JPEG)


The angle $\angle BOC$ is $\theta$, where $\theta<\tfrac{\pi}{2}$.
The area of the trapezium is $A\,$ cm$^2$.

- Show  $A=\tfrac{1}{2}r^2(\sin{2\theta}+2\sin{\theta})$.[3]

- Hence find the maximum value of $A$ in terms of $r$.[4]

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Helen is working with the function

$$
\begin{align*}
    f(x)&=e^{-x}(x-2)^2
\end{align*}
$$

where $x>0$.
She wants to learn more about its behaviour.

- Show that $f'(x)=-e^{-x}(x^2-6x+8)$. [2]

- Help Helen by finding $f''(x)$.[1]

- Hence, or otherwise find

  - the exact coordinates of any stationary points.
  - the nature of these stationary points.[6]



The function is concave down between $a<x<b$.

- Find $a$ and $b$ in the form $s \pm \sqrt{t}$ where $s, t \in \mathbb{Z}$. [4]

Helen begins looking at another function $g(x)$.
She knows that $g(2)=5$ and $g'(2)=3$.

- Find the exact value of $[f(g(2))]'$. [3]

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
[Maximum marks: 10]
The function $f(x)=a\sin{(bx)}+c$ where $0 \leq x \leq \pi$ and $a,b,c \in \mathrm{R}$ is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/0547420d-b08d-4f9e-bd37-d903d3be790b/AA1154.JPEG)


The coordinates of the first two stationary points are $(\tfrac{\pi}{6}, -1)$ and $(\tfrac{\pi}{2},3)$ respectively.

- Find

  - a.
  - c.
  - b. [5]



The domain of $f(x)$ is restricted to $\tfrac{\pi}{2}\leq x \leq k$, where $k \in \mathrm{R}$. This restriction allows an inverse to exist.

- Find the largest possible value of $k$. [2]

Another function is defined as $g(x)=-2f(\tfrac{1}{2}x)+3$.

- Determine the coordinates of the first maximum value of $g(x)$. [3]

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Consider the function

$$
\begin{align*}
    f(x)&=\tfrac{1}{4}x^2-x+3
\end{align*}
$$


- Write $f(x)$ in the form $a(x-h)^2+k$. Where $a, h, k \in \mathbb{Q}$. [3]

- Hence, find $\displaystyle \int f(x)\,dx$. [2]


A rectangle $ABCD$ has vertices shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/51c5c963-7f0e-489b-8337-0d8c9be7a46a/images/20472805-9641-4294-9664-c657a6cbe625/grid.JPEG)


$f(x)$ cuts the rectangle into two parts.
The part above the curve is labelled $U$ and the part below the curve is labelled $L$.

- 
  - Verify the point (4,3) lies on $f(x)$.
  - Hence, or otherwise, sketch $f(x)$ on the diagram above and identify the parts $U$ and $L$. [2]


- 
  - Write down the area of rectangle $ABCD$.
  - Hence, show that the area of $U$ is twice the area of $L$. [5]



The rectangle $ABCD$ is modified such that point $C(b, f(b))$ is a variable point on the function $f(x)$. Where $b>2$ and $b \in \mathbb{R}$.
The point $A(2, 2)$ is fixed in the same position as previously.

- Find the area of the new rectangle in terms of $b$.[2]

- Find $\displaystyle \int_{2}^{b}f(x)\,dx$ in terms of $b$.[1]

- Hence, or otherwise, prove that the area of $U$ is twice the area of $L$ for any position of point $C$. [4]
